'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Sunday, June 2, 2024 It’s remarkable that the world got not just one eccentric, Southern, witty, gay, troubled but brilliant writer in the 20th Century, but two. The lives and outsized personalities of Truman Capote and Tennessee Williams, who were colleagues, contemporaries, friends, and, occasionally, enemies, make for fascinating material in the documentary “Truman & Tennessee: An Intimate Conversation,” now streaming from the Jane Pickens Theater. The film’s clever pairing of their many separate television interviews, archival footage, and audio recordings creates a dual literary portrait of the artists, with back and forth dialogue full of their trademark acerbic barbs. What doesn’t exist in actual audio is recreated with voice-overs by actors Jim Parsons as Capote and Zachary Quinto as Williams. After listening to the distinctive voices of both men, it’s hard to hear the actors’ renditions as anything but pale imitations. To make it even more confusing, Parsons and Quinto sometimes sound alike. It’s a tall order, to be sure, but the actors are well cast. Quinto even played the Williams character in the 2014 re-vival of “The Glass Menagerie” on Broadway. Acclaimed playwright Tennessee Williams is one half of the literary duo profiled in the new documentary “Truman & Tennessee.” Capote’s legendary acerbic wit is on display in the film. Director Lisa Immordino Vreeland knows how to construct documentaries about larger-than-life cultural figures that present familiar material in a new way, starting with her 2011 documentary “Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel” about the groundbreaking career and personal style of her husband’s grandmother, renowned Vogue editor Diana Vreeland. Then came “Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addict” (2015) and “Love, Cecil: A Journey with Cecil Beaton,” her 2017 portrait of the Oscar-winning designer. Vreeland’s latest traces the familiar career trajectories of both writers but relies on their own words. Capote was a young, handsome curiosity when he burst onto the literary scene, changing it forever with one book, “In Cold Blood.” He became the darling of high society. Loren King is an arts and entertainment writer whose work appears regularly in The Boston Globe and other publications. Williams took Broadway by storm with successive hits, starting with “The Glass Menagerie” in 1944. This was followed by “A Streetcar Named Desire,” which unleashed Marlon Brando on an awed public, and then “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.” These landmark productions earned the playwright critical and commercial accolades. Many of his plays were made into memorable movies that live on in the public consciousness but were, he explains in the film, poor representations, since endings often were changed from the stage versions, most famously in “A Streetcar Named Desire,” because of Hollywood’s restrictive production code in the 1950s. At the height of their fame, Capote and Williams, along with their respective, longtime partners, Jack Dunphy and Frank Merlo, socialized together in lush vacation spots such as Venice and Capri. The two writers seemed to have a genuine bond as Southerners who were open about their homosexuality at a time when gays were ostracized and persecuted. It’s not surprising that both Capote and Williams abused alcohol and drugs. Both men talk candidly in interviews about their addictions and reveal that during the 1960s they were both patients of the notorious “Dr. Feelgood.” Each seemed to rely more and more on his scabrous wit to win attention, particularly from TV interviewers. The film’s lively clips of talk show appearances with Dick Cavett and David Frost remind us how smart and entertaining both interviewers were, and how deftly they handled difficult or taciturn guests. But at many times, Williams’s and Capote’s stories are suspect, since both often appear to be under the influence. At the time, this may have contributed to their allure, but now it just seems frustrating and sad. The film’s point is letting the men speak for themselves rather than relying on experts or insiders. For this kind of documentary, one should not miss director Ebs Burnough’s 2019 documentary, “The Capote Tapes.” It was Capote who crossed the line in betraying his friendship with Williams. Four chapters of Capote’s infamous, unfinished novel, “Answered Prayers,” appeared in Esquire magazine in 1975 and it triggered a scandal that destroyed Capote’s social standing. His thinly disguised, dishy portraits of his close friends included a mean-spirited character-based obviously on Williams. Although Williams was hurt and upset, he and Capote reconciled later in life. Perhaps as a mea culpa, Capote dedicated his 1980 collection, “Music for Chameleons,” to Williams. The film is most moving when it depicts two outsiders who, after being kicked around by teach other and by the rest of world, had no one else to turn to. It’s remarkable that the world got not just one eccentric, Southern, witty, gay, troubled but brilliant writer in the 20th Century, but two. The lives and outsized personalities of Truman Capote and Tennessee Williams, who were colleagues, contemporaries, friends, and, occasionally, enemies, make for fascinating material in the documentary “Truman & Tennessee: An Intimate Conversation,” now streaming from the Jane Pickens Theater. The film’s clever pairing of their many separate television interviews, archival footage, and audio recordings creates a dual literary portrait of the artists, with back and forth dialogue full of their trademark acerbic barbs. What doesn’t exist in actual audio is recreated with voice-overs by actors Jim Parsons as Capote and Zachary Quinto as Williams. After listening to the distinctive voices of both men, it’s hard to hear the actors’ renditions as anything but pale imitations. To make it even more confusing, Parsons and Quinto sometimes sound alike. It’s a tall order, to be sure, but the actors are well cast. Quinto even played the Williams character in the 2014 re-vival of “The Glass Menagerie” on Broadway. Acclaimed playwright Tennessee Williams is one half of the literary duo profiled in the new documentary “Truman & Tennessee.” Capote’s legendary acerbic wit is on display in the film. Director Lisa Immordino Vreeland knows how to construct documentaries about larger-than-life cultural figures that present familiar material in a new way, starting with her 2011 documentary “Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel” about the groundbreaking career and personal style of her husband’s grandmother, renowned Vogue editor Diana Vreeland. Paige Grissom, the Class of 2021 valedictorian, said learning how to think is the most important aspect of education.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 1.811883157643024e-05, 'sentence': '“I urge all of you to always look at data and come to your own conclusions,” Grissom said.', 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 2.3696931748418137e-05, 'sentence': '“Use common sense and personal discretion to make choices that are correct for you and your family rather than blindly allowing others to tell the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': "Chariho Regional High School’s Commencement Exercise for the Class of 2021 was held in person on the school’s athletic fields Friday night. WOOD RIVER JCT. — Walking across a stage set up on the football field for the first time in 19 years, 235 Chariho High School seniors received their diplomas and were reminded of lessons learned from the unusual year they just experienced. Parents, teachers, and invited members of the community watched the ceremony on the football field Friday evening as friends and family watched online. It was the first graduation ceremony to be held at the school since 2002; the past 18 have been held at the Ryan Center on the campus of the University of Rhode Island. In his opening address, Chariho High School Principal Craig MacKenzie said the COVID-19 pandemic has strengthened everyone’s resiliency. “While our school experience was more muted than in the past, we are kinder to each other, more appreciative of many aspects of schooling that we might have taken for granted, and more aware of how our attitudes and actions impact others,” he said. Marking his last graduation at Chariho, MacKenzie ended his remarks by telling the graduates, “I don’t take for granted that the promise I see in the eyes of the Class of 2021 inspires me to continue to grow as I make my next big move with you.” Paige Grissom, the Class of 2021 valedictorian, said learning how to think is the most important aspect of education. “I urge all of you to always look at data and come to your own conclusions,” Grissom said. “Use common sense and personal discretion to make choices that are correct for you and your family rather than blindly allowing others to tell you what is good for you and decide how you should live your life. We are all unique individuals who come from different circumstances and have different minds, so rather than believing the narrative presented to you, look beneath the surface and come to your own understanding of the world and its complexities.” In her speech, salutatorian Faith Ells told the graduating class that academic performance is not the absolute definition of success. “You have value no matter what,” Ells said. “You can do anything you want to, despite what others tell you. It takes hard work, grit, and determination, but you should not hold how you performed here in high school as your definition of success. “Do whatever you can to fight for the life you want. Use what you’ve learned here at Chariho, whether it be from positive or negative experiences, advocate for yourself, and work hard for what you want.” In her remarks to the graduating class, Chariho Superintendent of Schools Gina Picard compared the graduates’ choices to the words in a story. “We build our stories every day,” Picard said. “You are the writer of your own story. You take the pen every day, and one word at a time — one day at a time — your story is written. Life is your story. Choose the right words. “Your stories have only just begun,” she continued. “Choose your words carefully. The choices you make today will all be a part of your story … take your pen and continue to write a great story.” Log In Keep it Clean. Please avoid obscene, vulgar, lewd, racist or sexually-oriented language. PLEASE TURN OFF YOUR CAPS LOCK. Don't Threaten. Threats of harming another person will not be tolerated. Be Truthful. Don't knowingly lie about anyone or anything. Be Nice. No racism, sexism or any sort of -ism that is degrading to another person. Be Proactive. Use the 'Report' link on each comment to let us know of abusive posts. Share with Us. We'd love to hear eyewitness accounts, the history behind an article.
